title: 115_s513
content:
The Act is titled the "Frank and Jeanne Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area Designation Act." It includes findings related to the management area. Frank Moore, a WWII veteran and owner of the Steamboat Inn in Oregon, is honored for his dedication to family, country, and fly fishing. He was awarded the Chevalier of the French Legion of Honor for his bravery during the D-Day Allied invasion. Moore and his wife shared their love of fishing and the outdoors with visitors from around the world at their inn along the North Umpqua River. Frank Moore, a WWII veteran and owner of the Steamboat Inn in Oregon, has dedicated his life to fishing and conservation efforts. He has received multiple awards for his conservation work, including being inducted into the Fresh Water Fishing Hall of Fame. In recognition of his accomplishments, a large area of Forest Service land in Oregon is proposed to be named the "Frank and Jeanne Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area." SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

(1) Map - The map titled "Frank Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area Designation Act" dated June 23, 2016.
(2) Secretary - The Secretary of Agriculture, acting through the Chief of the Forest Service.
(3) Special management area - The Frank and Jeanne Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area designated by section 4(a).
(4) State - The State of Oregon.

SEC. 4. FRANK AND JEANNE MOORE WILD STEELHEAD SPECIAL MANAGEMENT AREA, OREGON. The approximately 99,653 acres of Forest Service land in Oregon is designated as the "Frank and Jeanne Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area" with a map and legal description available for public inspection. The "Frank and Jeanne Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area" in Oregon, consisting of approximately 99,653 acres of Forest Service land, is to be administered by the Secretary in accordance with laws applicable to the National Forest System. The area aims to conserve natural values, enhance habitat for wild salmonids, preserve watershed as a thermal refuge, and provide opportunities for recreation. The section addresses the jurisdiction of the State regarding fish and wildlife, adjacent management, wildfire management, and vegetation management within the Special Management Area. It clarifies that the State's responsibilities are not affected, no protective perimeter is created, and wildfire operations can be conducted in cooperation with other agencies. Vegetation management projects can be conducted within the Special Management Area in line with specified purposes and forest plans. Tribal treaty rights are protected, and Federal land within the area is withdrawn from various activities under public land and mining laws.
